items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Patricia Martinez-Roach, Board Clerk, and Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Kirsten King, Interim Director of Instructional ServicesSUBJECT:Discussion and/or Action to Amend Board Policies:6155.1 Grades/Evaluation of Student Achievement6154 Homework/Makeup Work6146.2 Certificate of High School Equivalency Achievement5121 Grades/Evaluation of Student Achievement5121.1 Examinations, Finals5113 Absences and ExcusesThe Board has approved many Board policies relating to the assignment of student grades. The following is a list of a few of the most pertinent grading policies:6155.1 INSTRUCTION - Grades/Evaluation of Student Achievement6154 INSTRUCTION - Homework/Makeup Work6146.2 INSTRUCTION -Certificate of High School Equivalency Achievement5121 STUDENTS - Grades/Evaluation of Student Achievement5121.1 STUDENTS - Examinations, Finals5113 STUDENTS - Absences and ExcusesThe Instructional Services Division feels that, while it is appropriate to have grading referenced in many policies, it is confusing not to have one cohesive Board policy on grading to reference. To rectify the situation, the Instructional Services Division requests that the Board of Trustees direct the Division to consolidate, clarify, and create one cohesive policy on grading that combines all of the Board approved grading policies into one policy and be brought back to the Board for reading and adoption.FISCAL IMPACT:Not ApplicableFUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees direct the Instructional Services Division to consolidate, clarify and create one cohesive Board policy on grading that combines all of the Board approved grading policies, #6155.1, #6154, #6146.2, #5121, #5121.1 and #5113, into one policy and be brought back upon completion to the Board for reading and adoption.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTResolution in Support of Robles-Wong v. California,Litigation Challenging the State’s School Finance SystemResolution #2009/2010-49WHEREAS, education is a fundamental right of every child in California; and WHEREAS, California’s constitution requires a public school system that prepares students to become informed citizens and productive members of society; and WHEREAS, California has set clear requirements for what schools are expected to teach and what students are expected to learn; and WHEREAS, the State has an obligation to maintain and support a school finance system that provides districts and county offices of education the resources necessary to meet these requirements; and WHEREAS, California’s school finance system is unsound, unstable, insufficient, and thus unconstitutional; and WHEREAS, the State’s school finance system prevents the East Side Union High School District from providing all of the education programs and services our students need to become proficient in the State’s academic standards and to obtain a well-rounded education; and WHEREAS, as a result of the broken school finance system, students are being denied the opportunity to master the required education program; and WHEREAS, severe budget cuts over the last several years have made a dire situation worse by forcing districts to increase class size, lay off teachers, eliminate many programs necessary to support student learning and well-being; and WHEREAS, the lawsuit, Robles-Wong v. California, filed on May 20, 2010 in Alameda County seeks to remedy the broken school finance system by (1) declaring it unconstitutional and (2) requiring State lawmakers to uphold their constitutional duty to design and implement a school finance system that provides all students equal access to the required education program; and WHEREAS, filing this lawsuit was a last resort — the Governor and lawmakers have known for some time that the current school finance system is harming students, schools and districts, and they have done nothing to remedy the crisis; and WHEREAS, the East Side Union High School District believes it is imperative to provide a sound, stable, and sufficient school finance system so that all children have equal educational opportunities; NOW, THERFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the East Side Union High School District strongly supports Robles-Wong v. California, the litigation challenging the State’s school finance system. PASSED AND ADOPTED this 17th day of June 2010 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California. AYES:   ________NOES:  ________ABSENT:  ______ABSTAIN:  ______I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on June 17, 2010._________________________ClerkESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Approve 2010 Single Plan for Student AchievementThe purpose of the Single Plan for Student Achievement (SPSA) is to create a cycle of continuous improvement of student performance, and to ensure that all students succeed in reaching academic standards set by the State Board of Education.The 2010-2011 SPSA have been completed by each school and dully reviewed and approved by School Site Councils. Four of the Title I schools (Andrew Hill, James Lick, W.C. Overfelt and Yerba Buena) are designated as School-wide Title I schools as per board action in 2005.  The schools attained this status due to high number of students (at least 40% of enrollment) on Free/Reduced meals. This year, the remaining five Title I schools (Foothill, Independence, Mt. Pleasant, Oak Grove and Silver Creek) have at least 40 percent of their students eligible for Free/Reduced meals. Therefore, these schools are now qualified to apply to become a School-wide Title I school upon board approval. A School-wide Title I school will have more flexibility in using the allocated funds to support all students.The District Advisory Council (DAC) and the District English Learners Advisory Council (DELAC) have reviewed the school goals, budgets, and plans. The abstracts for the school plans are included in this packet while complete copies of the plans are available for Trustee review in the Instructional Services Division, as requested.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:State:  School Improvement Program (SIP), Economic Impact Aid (EIA). GATE, Tenth Grade CounselingFederal:  Title I, Title II – Professional Development, Title III English Learners and ImmigrantsRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve 2010 Single Plan for Student Achievement as indicated herein, and that the Superintendent be authorized to make modifications as needed.
items.item_text: Approve 2010 Single Plan for Student Achievement - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
items.item_text_raw: 10.02 Approve 2010 Single Plan for Student Achievement - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Tim Nguyen, Coordinator of English Language Learners Supplementary EducationSUBJECT:Approve Applications for Title I School-Wide Program StatusA school-wide program is a comprehensive reform strategy designed to upgrade the entire educational program in a Title I school; its primary goal is to ensure that all students, particularly those who are low-achieving, demonstrate proficient and advanced levels of achievement on State academic achievement standards.In general, a Title I school may operate as a school-wide program only if a minimum of 40 percent of the students in the school, or residing in the attendance area served by the school, are from low-income families. [Section 1114(a)(1) of Title I of ESEA].Whereas, Title I targeted assistance programs only provide educational services to identified individual students, school-wide programs allow staff in schools with high concentrations of students from low-income families to redesign their entire educational program to serve all students. The emphasis in school-wide program schools is on serving all students, improving all structures that support student learning, and combining all resources, as allowed, to achieve a common goal. School-wide programs maximize the impact of Title I. Adopting this strategy should result in an ongoing, comprehensive plan for school improvement that is owned by the entire school community and tailored to its unique needs. Based on current data provided by our food services department, 41% of Oak Grove High School students are eligible for Free/Reduced meals, 60% of Foothill High School students are eligible for Free/Reduced meals, 45% of Silver Creek High School students are eligible for Free/Reduced meals, 41% of Independence High school students are eligible for Free/Reduced meals, and 50% of Mt. Pleasant High School students are eligible for Free/Reduced meals.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Federal: Title IRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the applications for Title I school-wide status as indicated herein, and that the Superintendent be authorized to make modifications as needed.

items.item_text_raw: 10.03 Approve Applications for Title I School-wide Program Status - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Tim Nguyen, Coordinator of English Language Learners Supplementary Education

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Approve New Courses:	Marine Biology	Multimedia Arts IIIThe Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) has reviewed the Marine Biology and Multimedia Arts III courses.  These courses were piloted during the 2009 - 2010 school year.  The course descriptions are included for your review.  Marine Biology: Marine Biology will fill the need for an additional life science option within our district elective science class offerings. The course will be available to junior and senior students who have completed their physical and biological science requirements for graduation. Marine Biology is a third or fourth year of science elective course emphasis on ecology and the world’s marine environment will provide the sort of timeliness and relevance that will attract additional students who might not otherwise choose a third year elective science course.Multimedia Arts III: Multimedia Arts III is an intermediate/advanced level, project-based course that provides students with the opportunity to further explore and refine what they learned in Multimedia Arts I and II. Course emphasis is on time-based design supported by video and audio production tools. Students revisit studies of the integration of text, images, animation and interactivity in the creation of multimedia projects while exploring advanced techniques and concepts in art and technology. Students will further research career and educational pathways, along with developing a professional portfolio and planning the pieces to achieve college entrance or career attainment. Students will be introduced to employability skills, certification and transition. Successful completion of Multimedia Arts III will prepare students for college art courses and have advanced skills in the visual arts, media, technology and presentation.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the courses above.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Adopt Santa Clara County Office of Education / East Side Union High School District’s Plan for Expelled YouthAs mandated by Education Code 48926, each county superintendent of schools in counties that operate community schools pursuant to Section 1980, in conjunction with superintendents of the school districts within the county, shall develop a plan for providing education services to all expelled pupils in that county.  The plans shall be adopted by the governing board of each school district within the county and by the county board of education.The plan shall enumerate existing education alternatives for expelled pupils, identify gaps in educational services to expelled pupils, and strategies for filling those service gaps.  The plan shall also identify alternative placements for pupils who are expelled and placed in district community day school programs, but who fail to meet the terms of the conditions of their rehabilitation plan or who pose a danger to other district pupils, as determined by the governing board.Each county superintendent of schools, in conjunction with the superintendents of the school districts, shall submit to the Superintendent of Public Instruction the county plan for providing educational services to all expelled pupils in the county no later than June 30, 2010, and shall submit a triennial update to the plan to the Superintendent of Public Instruction, including the outcome data pursuant to Section 48916.1, on June 30th thereafter.Per Education Code 48916.1, at the time an expulsion of a pupil is order, the governing board of the school district shall ensure that an educational program is provided to the pupil who is subject to the expulsion order for the period of the expulsion, but only to the extent funds are appropriated for this purpose in the annual budget Act or other legislation, or both.FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the Santa Clara County Office of Education / East Side Union High School District’s Plan for Expelled Youth.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent,Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:20 p.m.regarding Tentative Agreement with East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA, August 31, 2010 – August 31, 2011, and Disclosure of Major Provisions of Tentative Agreement (AB1200)In accordance with Assembly Bill 1200 requiring school districts to disclose, at a public meeting, the cost that would be incurred by the implementation of a collective bargaining agreement.  In meeting the requirement, a public hearing is being held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA.  The District and the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA reached a tentative agreement on May 14, 2010. items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent,Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators as NeededIn July 1994, the Commission on Teacher Credentialing changed the process for emergency credentialing.  Prior to that time, districts were required to issue individual statements of need for each applicant.  The applicant, in turn, would take the declaration of need to the county office of education for the issuance of an emergency credential. This applies to the following credentials or authorizations: Emergency CLAD, BCLAD, Resource Specialist, Library Media, Clinical or Rehabilitative Permits.Now, the Commission issues a permit to an individual who qualifies for an emergency based on the district’s Declaration of Need.  This Declaration, approved by the local Board of Trustees, is submitted to the Commission once a year.  Emergency permits, although originally used primarily to staff partial assignments and special education, now help fill the fully credentialed teacher gap created by class size reduction and statewide teacher shortage.  Every attempt is being made to hire credentialed teachers before considering people on emergency permits.  Attached is the Commission on Teacher Credentialing form titled Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.  Pursuant to direction from the county office of education’s credential’s office, the district is over estimating the number of permits it might require in order to cover any unanticipated needs that might occur during the course of the 2010-2011 school year.FISCAL IMPACT: As per salary scheduleFUNDING SOURCE: General, Special Education and Adult Education fundsRECOMMENDATION: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services and Rogelio Ruiz, Legal CounselSUBJECT:Adopt Resolution #2009/2010-50 Intention to Lease District Property for Cellular and Wireless Communication Antenna Purposes The District has received additional interest from cellular and wireless communication providers to lease property at the district’s school sites and other facilities for the purpose of installing and maintaining cellular and wireless communication antennas.  The Board has previously awarded such lease agreements to carriers Verizon, T-Mobile and Clear Wire.  Antennas potentially would be installed on light poles around the football stadiums at each of those campuses, on rooftops, or as otherwise approved by the District.  Other school districts have entered into such agreements as a means of generating lease income including, most recently, San Jose Unified School District.  Administration seeks the Board’s approval to accept additional lease proposals at all of the District’s sites.At the September 17, 2009, Regular Board Meeting, the Board held a public hearing to solicit community input on the potential leasing of District property for such purposes.  Before Administration can fully negotiate any such lease with any proposed lessee the Board must by 2/3ds vote (4 out of 5 Members) approve a Resolution of Intent to lease property and then advertise the notice of the approved resolution locally, including that the District will be accepting offers to lease such property upon minimum rental terms.  Each lease could generate approximately $24,000 annually, or more.Any offers to lease would be opened and examined at the time of the August 19, 2010, regular Board meeting, and any lease agreements would be subject to final Board approval.FISCAL IMPACT:Lease revenue to be determinedFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the attached Resolution no. #2009/2010-50 by a 2/3rds majority declaring the District’s intent to lease District property as described in the Resolution.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Approve the Tax Exempt Master Equipment Lease Purchase Agreement with Bank of AmericaOn May 20, 2010 the Board of Trustees adopted Resolution #2009/2010-46 approving an energy services contract and authorizing a lease purchase agreement for the purpose of financing a portion of the solar renewable energy project, designating the master equipment lease purchase agreement as a tax exempt obligation.  The amount of the financed portion of the project is $14,619,998.  The District sent requests for proposals to six finance agencies and received three proposals in response.  The responses received were from First Security Leasing; Bank of America and Green Campus Corp.  Two of the proposals also included financing under a new offering known as Build America Bond Taxable Lease Purchase.  This program does provide for lease purchase funds at an initial higher taxable interest rate than the non-taxable financing.  However, under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) the federal government on an annual basis would reimburse the District 35% of the interest cost which would net a slightly less interest cost to the District than a non taxable lease purchase arrangement.  This reimbursement would have to be requested at the end of each year of principle and interest payments to the leaser.  This would be over the full fifteen year period of lease payback.  Under this program there would not be a provision for an early payback or pay down of the obligation.  Under the Green Campus Corporation offer the Build America Bond program is also a General Obligation Bond proposal with interest rates based upon closing the sale of bonds with the underwriter.  Other than the Bank of America offer the interest rates proposed were not locked.  Staff is recommending not participating in this untested form of financing.  Of the other two proposals that were for a tax exempt lease purchase financing the lowest guaranteed interest rate of 4.51% is from Bank of America.  The Bank of America proposal does include a provision under certain circumstances for early pay-down or payback of the loan.  The staff does recommend accepting the Bank of America proposal.FISCAL IMPACT:$14,619,998.00FUNDING SOURCERetirement of the 15 year Debt will be paid from the project energy cost savingsRECOMMENDATION:It is recommend that the Board of Trustees accept and approve the Bank of America proposal for a tax exempt master equipment lease purchase agreement in the amount of $14,619,998 at an interest rate not to exceed 4.51%.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education StudentsDESCRIPTION: DESCRIPTION:  Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student’s parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:1)	An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.2)	Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.3)	An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination while using a modification that fundamentally alters what the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students’ parents.The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in Education Code Section 60851: Student A	Student B 	Student C 	Student D 	FISCAL IMPACT:NAFUNDING SOURCE:NARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.
items.item_text: Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
items.item_text_raw: 15.05 Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
